''Past experience'' and examples are both great tools for learning. Even in the realm of PokÃ©mon combat this is true; having witnessed a Move and being able to study its dynamics is an extremely useful thing. And what better way to do this than to have it recorded?<br>
''Chroniclers'' capitalize on this concept, getting close to the fray and capturing the finest details on how a Move is executed, whether through photography, artistic appreciation that later becomes a painting or other work of art, or analysis that goes into a journal. From this they can learn how to best avoid it in the future, and potentially even teach their PokÃ©mon to use it.<br>
''The Chronicler'' Class introduces bonuses for keeping Records of Moves and Environments, but its main draw is an alternative tutoring method using these Records. These Features allow you to take the Moves you commonly see and turn them against your foes. Additionally, its low entry requirements and reliance on universally useful Skill make it a nice class for Trainers who donâ€™t specialize in Trainer Combat.

* ''Chronicler''
** [Class]
** Prerequisites: Perception 3
** 1 AP â€“ Swift Action, Interrupt
** Target: A PokÃ©mon, Trainer, Move, or Location.
** Effect: You make Record of the target. Records can be placed in an Archive as an Extended Action. When you take Chronicler, you gain one Archive.
** ''Archives:''
*** Profile Archive: You may place Records of PokÃ©mon and Trainers in your Profile Archive. You gain a +2 bonus to Charm, Guile, Command, Intimidate, and Intuition Checks targeting PokÃ©mon and Trainers in your Profile Archive.
*** Technique Archive: You may place Records of Moves in your Technique Archive. You and your PokÃ©mon gain +2 Evasion against Moves in your Technique Archives.
*** Travel Archive: You may place Records of Locations in your Travel Archive. When you gain Travel Archive, choose Keen Eye or Perception. While you are in a Location in your Travel Archive, you have the Chosen Ability and gain a +2 bonus to Perception Checks to notice the environment.

* ''Archival Training''
** [Ranked 2]
** All Rank Prerequisites: Chronicler
** Effect: Each Rank, you gain an Archive.

* ''Archive Tutor''
** Prerequisites: Technique Archive, Perception 5
** Daily â€“ Extended Action
** Target: A PokÃ©mon with 2 Tutor Points.
** Effect: Select a Record in your Technique Archive that is of a Move that the target can learn by Level Up, TM or by Move Tutor. The target learns the Move and loses 2 Tutor Points. You can target someone elseâ€™s PokÃ©mon only once with Archive Tutor; you may target your own PokÃ©mon any number of times with Archive Tutor, but they must still abide by any Move Pool Limitations (ie: no more than 3 of the userâ€™s Move Pool can come from TMs or Tutor Moves).

* ''Targeted Profiling''
** [Orders]
** Prerequisites: Profile Archive, Perception 5
** 2 AP â€“ Standard Action
** Target: Your PokÃ©mon
** Effect: On the targetâ€™s next turn, they act as if they had the Mold Breaker Ability against all PokÃ©mon and Trainers in your Profile Archive and gains a +2 bonus to Accuracy Rolls against these targets.

* ''Observation Party''
** Prerequisites: Travel Archive, Perception 4
** Effect: While they are in a Location in your Travel Archive, your PokÃ©mon have the Ability you chose when gaining Travel Archive and gain a +2 bonus to Perception Checks to notice the environment.

* ''Cinematic Analysis''
** Prerequisites: 4 Chronicler Features, Perception 6
** Daily x3 â€“ Free Action
** Effect: You analyze a Record in one of your Archives. Cinematic Analysisâ€™s effect depends on the Archive the Record is in. Each of these effects may only be used once per Scene.
*** Character Study â€“ Profile Archive: You may trigger Character Study when you or an ally makes a Charm, Command, Guile, Intimidate, or Intuition Check targeting the subject of your Record. Make a Perception Check and substitute the triggering Skill Check with the result.
*** Recreation â€“ Technique Archive: Recreation may be triggered as your PokÃ©mon gains Initiative. Select a Record of a Move in your Technique Archive that your PokÃ©mon can learn by Level Up, TM, or Move Tutor. Your PokÃ©mon may perform that Move as if it was on its Move List. You may select a specific Move only once per day.
*** Situational Awareness â€“ Travel Archive: You may only use Situational Awareness if you analyze a Record of your current Location. When used this way, you may activate it as an Interrupt. Choose an ally; that ally may take their next action as Priority (Advanced).






!! Class Rules

* Trainers may take 4 classes by the end of the game.
* Trainers start with 4 (+1) Feature points, and gain more as they level up. These are divided between classes and General Features.
* A Class, and all the abilities listed under it, count as features towards that class.
* Each Class and Feature may only be taken once unless otherwise noted.
* A ''Branching Class'', like Type Ace, has multiple sub-classes. You must choose just one of these when taking the Class. You may take the class multiple times, choosing a different specialty each time, and each one counts as a separate class.

!! Introductory Classes

* [[Ace Trainer|Ace Trainer]]
** A generalist battler that makes the most of Training Features and downtime training to ensure their PokÃ©mon are always in peak condition.
* [[Capture Specialist|Capture Specialist]]
** Gotta catch â€˜em all! An expert at using PokÃ© Balls and other capture tools to their maximum potential.
* [[Commander|Commander]]
** A leader and expert at using Orders with efficiency to coordinate their allies on the battlefield. They may stand in the back of a fight, but they definitely take an active role in ensuring their partyâ€™s victory.
* [[Coordinator|Coordinator]]
** PokÃ©monâ€™s not just about battles. Coordinators take to the stage in PokÃ©mon Contests to show off their companions in exciting and fabulous ways, but they can hold their own in a battle as well.
* [[Hobbyist|Hobbyist]]
** A jack of all trades, perfect for characters who arenâ€™t committed to a certain path yet. Hobbyists dabble in a variety of fields and can gain talents representing many different roles.
* [[Mentor|Mentor]]
** Preparation is half the battle. Mentors are skilled caretakers of PokÃ©mon that know how to draw out their potential, whether by changing the Nature of a PokÃ©mon or teaching it new Moves to give them an edge in battle.

!! Battling Style Classes

* [[Cheerleader|Cheerleader]]
** One of four Classes based on the four Training Features, Cheerleader expands on the battling style of the Inspired Training Feature. Theyâ€™re able to motivate their allies with Orders and are great for a Trainer with PokÃ©mon that can defend and support allies.
* [[Duelist|Duelist]]
** One of four Classes based on the four Training Features, Duelist hones in on the Focused Training Feature and the battling style it promotes. Their core mechanic is based on controlling the momentum of battle and gaining a steady advantage using one PokÃ©mon at a time without much switching.
* [[Enduring Soul|Enduring Soul]]
** A defensive Class that seeks to outlast its opponents, the Enduring Soul can give even the most frail PokÃ©mon immense staying power. They may not aim to hit the hardest, but they will be sure to remain standing at the end of the day.
* [[Juggler|Juggler]]
** Jugglers swiftly swap through their entire PokÃ©mon teams in a fight, forcing opponents to keep on their toes. They can make the most of a versatile team by ensuring that they always have the PokÃ©mon they want out facing their foes and catching them off guard.
* [[Rider|Rider]]
** One of four Classes based on the four Training Features, Rider makes the most of Agility Training by applying it to the art of mounted combat. From the back of their PokÃ©mon, they can bark Orders or swat away would-be attackers that get too close. Trainer and PokÃ©mon work in concert to create a devastating combination.
* [[Taskmaster|Taskmaster]]
** One of four Classes based on the four Training Features, Taskmaster embraces the cruel battling style of the Brutal Training Feature. It is a high-risk, high-reward Class that gains an offensive edge at the expense of giving their own PokÃ©mon Injuries through a grueling training regime.
* [[Trickster|Trickster]]
** Tricksters are specialists in commanding their PokÃ©mon to use Status-Class Moves, whether they are inflicting their foes with Poison and Burn, flooding the battlefield with Hazards, or weakening their opponents with Combat Stage reducing Moves.

!! Specialist Team Classes

* [[Stat Ace|Stat Ace]]
** A specialist in one of the five Combat Stats: Attack, Defense, Special Attack, Special Defense, and Speed.
* [[Style Expert|Style Expert]]
** An advanced Contest competitor that specializes in one of the five Contest Stats: Beauty, Cool, Cute, Smart, and Tough. They have battling styles that reflect their Contest specialization as well.
* [[Type Ace|Type Ace]]
** A battler that primarily uses PokÃ©mon of a certain elemental Type.

!! Professional Classes

* [[Chef|Chef]]
** A crafting Class that creates food for them and their allies, which can provide an instant buff in battle and turn the tide.
* [[Chronicler|Chronicler]]
** A perceptive type of Trainer who records everything they run across for posterity. Analyzing their records not only gives them insight into people and places, but also an edge in battle and the ability to Tutor Moves to their PokÃ©mon.
* [[Fashionista|Fashionista]]
** A crafting Class that makes Held Items for all sorts of different occasions and can teach their PokÃ©mon to make better use of Held Items.
* [[Researcher|Researcher]]
** Researchers study various academic fields and apply them to PokÃ©mon: General Knowledge, Apothecary, Botany, Chemistry, Climatology, Crystal Artifice, Occultism, Paleontology, and PokÃ©mon Caretaking.
* [[Survivalist|Survivalist]]
** A wilderness-oriented Class that can specialize in a variety of terrains, gaining the ability to create impromptu traps, fight using the environment, and help their allies cope with their surroundings.

!! Fighter Classes

* [[Athlete|Athlete]]
** A front-line fighter who specializes in training themselves and boosting their Stats.
* [[Dancer|Dancer]]
** A supportive Class which can boost its own Combat Stages as well as those of its allies. Best as a supplementary Class, paired with other Fighter Classes.
* [[Hunter|Hunter]]
** A unique fighter who works best when cooperating with their PokÃ©mon to corner foes and assault them with Attacks of Opportunity.
* [[Martial Artist|Martial Artist]]
** A front-line fighter that can specialize in a variety of fighting styles and excels at Fighting-Type offense.
* [[Musician|Musician]]
** A versatile supporter and Special Attacker that can swap between debuffing foes, buffing allies, and attacking with sound-based Moves on a whim.
* [[Provocateur|Provocateur]]
** Mislead, frighten, and seduce. The Provocateur specializes in disorienting Social Moves and the Manipulate Maneuver.
* [[Rogue|Rogue]]
** A tricky fighter that excels in Dark-Type offense and using the Dirty Fighting Combat Maneuver.
* [[Roughneck|Roughneck]]
** A fighter specializing in using fear to overwhelm their foes. They can not only debuff their opponents but also come with a suite of Features and Moves to improve their survivability in battle.
* [[Tumbler|Tumbler]]
** A quick fighter based on mobility and Flying-Type offense.

!! Fantasy Expansion

* [[Arcanist|Arcanist]]
* [[Berserker|Berserker]]
* [[Fortress|Fortress]]
* [[Marksman|Marksman]]
* [[Rune Master|Rune Master]]
* [[Skirmisher|Skirmisher]]

!! Supernatural Classes

* [[Channeler|Channeler]]
** A Class with the ability to bond closely with PokÃ©mon and link them together with a mystical power for potent synergy in battle.
* [[Hex Maniac|Hex Maniac]]
** Hex Maniacs fight their foes using curses and hexes that debilitate and disable them.
* [[Ninja|Ninja]]
** A stealthy fighter with many tricks up its sleeve, such as Hazards, Illusions, and Poisoned Weapons.
* [[Oracle|Oracle]]
** Oracles are mystics who can read the lines of fate and divine the future with their powers.
* [[Sage|Sage]]
** Sages defend and protect their allies with Blessing Moves.
* [[Telekinetic|Telekinetic]]
** Telekinetics are Psychics who can move objects from afar, letting them wield weapons from across the battlefield, or toss foes up in the fair to flail helplessly.
* [[Telepath|Telepath]]
** Mind readers who have a focus on out-of-battle investigation with their powers but can mentally assault their foes as well.
* [[Warper|Warper]]
** Warpers are teleporting Psychics that arenâ€™t great in combat on their own but pair very well with other fighting Classes.

!! Elementalist Classes

* [[Bug: Swarmlord|Swarmlord]]
* [[Dark: Shade Caller|Shade Caller]]
* [[Dragon: Herald of Pride|Herald of Pride]]
* [[Electric: Spark Master|Spark Master]]
* [[Fairy: Glamour Weaver|Glamour Weaver]]
* [[Fighting: Aura Guardian|Aura Guardian]]
** Mystics who specialize in reading the Auras of others. High in Fighting-Type offense.
* [[Fire: Fire Bringer|Fire Bringer]]
* [[Flying: Wind Runner|Wind Runner]]
* [[Ghost: Apparition|Apparition]]
* [[Grass: Druid|Druid]]
* [[Ground: Earth Shaker|Earth Shaker]]
* [[Ice: Frost Touched|Frost Touched]]
* [[Normal: Prism|Prism]]
* [[Poison: Miasmic|Miasmic]]
* [[Rock: Stone Warrior|Stone Warrior]]
* [[Steel: Steelheart|Steelheart]]
* [[Water: Maelstrom|Maelstrom]]






! Size
* Small or Medium creatures are 1x1
* Large creatures are 2x2
* Huge creatures are 3x3
* Gigantic Creatures are 4x4

! Movement
* Using multiple types of movement takes the average of the used types.
* Jumping takes from the total movement for the turn.
* When Slowed, creatures move at half speed.
* When Stuck, creatures cannot move at all.

! Terrain
* Regular - No effects. Any mostly smooth and flat ground, such as roads or short grass
* Water - Requires Swimming Speed. Any water deeper than half the target's height.
* Earth - Requires Burrow Speed.
* Slow Terrain - Halves Movement. Pokemon with the appropriate Naturewalk may ignore this effect.
* Rough Terrain - -2 AC when targeting into or through Rough Terrain. Occupied Spaces count as Rough Terrain. Rough Terrain is often Slow as well.







! Attack of Opportunity
* Free Action: When triggered, you may make a Struggle attack against the trigger as an Interrupt. May be used once per round, Cannot be used while Sleeping, Flinched, or Paralyzed.
* Triggered when an adjacent foe:
** ...uses Push, Grapple, Disarm, Trip, or Dirty Trick that does not target you.
** ...stands up.
** ...uses a ranged attack that does not target someone next to it.
** ...uses a standard action to pick up or retrieve an item.
** ...shifts out of a grid adjacent to you.

! Disengage
* Shift Action: You may shift 1m, this does not provoke an attack of opportunity.

! Disarm
* Standard Action, AC 6, Status, Melee, 1 Target: Make opposed Combat or Stealth checks. If you win, the target drops their held item.

! Dirty Trick
* Standard Action, AC 2, Status, Melee, 1 Target: You may use each trick once per scene per target.
** Hinder: Make opposed Athletics checks. The target is Slowed and takes -2 to all skill checks for one round.
** Blind: Make opposed Stealth checks. The target is Blinded for one round.
** Low Blow: Make opposed Acrobatics checks. The target becomes Vulnerable with 0 Initiative until the end of your next turn.

! Manipulate
* Standard Action, AC 2, Status, Range 6, 1 Target
* May only be performed by trainers. Limit once per scene per target.
** Bon Mot: Make a Guile check opposed by Guile or Focus. The target is enraged and cannot spend AP for one round, without a Save check.
** Flirt: Make a Charm check opposed by Charm or Focus. The target is Infatuated with you for one round, without a Save check.
** Terrorize: Make an Intimidate check opposed by Intimidate or Focus. The target loses all Temp HP and can only use At-Will moves for one round.

! Push
* Standard Action, AC 4, Status, Melee, 1 Target
* Make opposing Athletics of Combat checks. The target is pushed 1m away from you. If you have movement left, you may move into the unoccupied space and continue pushing. You may not push a target heavier than your heavy lifting Capability.

! Sprint
* Standard Action, Status, Self
* Increase all movement speeds by 50% for the rest of your turn.

! Trip
* Standard Action, AC 6, Status, Melee, 1 Target
* Make opposed Combat or Acrobatics checks. The target is knocked over and Tripped.

! Intercept Melee
* Full Action, Interrupt, Status
* When an Ally within movement range is hit by an adjacent foe, Make an Acrobatics or Athletics check with DC 3x distance to target. You push the ally 1m away, occupy their space, and are hit by the attack
* On failure, user still shifts equal to one third their roll.
* You may attempt to intercept and area-of-effect attack, but it might not prevent the ally from taking damage.

! Intercept Ranged
* Full Action, Interrupt, Status
* When a Ranged X-Target attack passes within your movement range, select a square in the path of the attack. Make an Acrobatics or Athletics check. You may shift half of the result towards the chosen square. If you succeed, you take the hit instead of the target.
* You may only intercept Priority and Interrupt moves if you are faster than the attacker.
* Moves that cannot miss cannot be intercepted.
* You cannot intercept if you are Asleep, Confused, Enraged, Frozen, Stuck, Paralyzed, or otherwise unable to move.
* You may not use intercepts to protect someone who is also using an intercept.

! Grapple
* Standard Action, AC 4, Status, Melee, 1 Target
* Make opposed Combat or Athletics Checks, you and the target become grappled, and you gain Dominance.
* If you are grappled, you are Vulnerable, cannot shift, and take -6 AC towards anyone outside the grapple.
* If a participant begins their turn in a grapple without dominance, they may contest it as a full action. The winner may continue the grapple and gain dominance, or choose to end it.
* If a participant begins their turn with dominance, they may take a following actions as a full action:
** Secure: +3 to next opposed check in the grapple
** Attack: automatically hit with an unarmed struggle attack
** Move: Shift, dragging the other person in the grapple with them. Movement is hindered by the opponentâ€™s weight class.
* A participant with Phasing or Teleporter capability may escape the grapple without a check.

! Take A Breather
* Full Action: Shift as far away from combat as possible, becoming tripped and vulnerable for one round.
** Reset Combat Stages to Default
** Lose Temp HP
** Cure Volatile Status, Slowed, and Stuck Conditions
** Cure Curse if the curser is KOâ€™ed or at least 12m away.
* Cannot independently â€˜Take a Breatherâ€™ if
** Enraged
** Failed the turnâ€™s Confusion Save
* If you cannot 'Take a Breather' you can still be calmed and assisted by a trainer. This is a full action for both parties, as the assistant must shift to the target and make a DC 12 command check. If successful, both parties shift away together and both â€˜Take a Breatherâ€™.







''Commanders'' are authoritative trainers that focus on PokÃ©mon battling. Commanders prefer to stand in the back lines, and direct their allies through battle, like a conductor leading a grand orchestra. Their versatility is their greatest strength, and one they are often eager and proud to use. <br>
''Commanders'' tend to be fond of complex plans and tactical set-ups; as such, they make more effective and efficient use of the Orders Features that are available to all Trainers through General Features and synergize well with other Classes that have their own Orders too. They are experts at organizing deadly and well-coordinated assaults.<br>

* ''Commander''
** [Class]
** Prerequisites: Command 3
** Effect: Choose one of Ravager Orders, Marksman Orders, Trickster Orders, Guardian Orders, or Precision Orders. You gain the chosen Feature, even if you do not meet its prerequisites.

* ''Mobilize''
** [Orders]
** Prerequisites: Commander
** At-Will â€“ Free Action
** Target: Any Ally
** Effect: The target cannot provoke Attacks of Opportunity on their next turn. Mobilize may target an Ally only once per encounter.

* ''Leadership''
** Prerequisites: Commander
** Effect: You may use [Orders] that have targets to target any Ally, even if normally those [Orders] would only let you apply the effect to your own Pokemon. Any other conditions still apply.

* ''Battle Conductor''
** Prerequisites: Leadership
** At-Will â€“ Swift Action
** Trigger: You give [Orders] with a Frequency of At-Will that have targets
** Effect: You may target up to two additional Allies with the [Orders].
** Note: This may be used with [Orders] that are have AP costs, but the AP Cost must be paid separately for each target if so.

* ''Complex Orders''
** Prerequisites: Mastermind, at least two Features with the [Orders] Tag that have targets
** At-Will â€“ Shift Action
** Trigger: You give [Orders] that have targets.
** Effect: You may choose a different Order to give to each Target. You must pay all AP costs and follow Frequency restrictions for all Orders used in this way.

* ''Tip the Scales''
** Prerequisites: Commander, Command 5
** 2 AP â€“ Swift Action
** Trigger: You give [Orders] that have targets.
** Effect: Your [Orders] with an At-Will Frequency instead target all allies within 10 Meters.

* ''Scheme Twist''
** Prerequisites: Commander, Command 6
** Scene x2 â€“ Swift Action
** Trigger: You give [Orders] with a Daily or Scene Frequency that have Targets.
** Effect: You may target up to two additional Allies with the [Orders].






''Coordinators'' specialize not in PokÃ©mon Battles, but in PokÃ©mon Contests. In PokÃ©mon Contests, PokÃ©mon compete not to hurt each other, but to use their attacks and abilities to impress the contest judges and the watching crowds. The world of PokÃ©mon Contests is just as competitive as the PokÃ©mon Battling scene, and so itâ€™s not enough to merely groom a PokÃ©monâ€™s physical appearance; Coordinators must learn to guide their PokÃ©mon to act with grace and charm, and innovate so they can stand out from the crowds. In facing these challenges, Coordinators naturally acquire an ability for guidance and leadership, and this talent for directing others can even be exploited to their benefit in battle; here they can distract and disrupt enemies, or bolster their allies with encouragement or opportunities.<br>
''Although'' many Coordinators shun PokÃ©mon Battles, ironically their training improves the Battle abilities of their PokÃ©mon too. Their PokÃ©mon learn to stay calm under pressure and give it their all, whether on the stage or the arena. And like Ace Trainers, the sheer amount of dedication Coordinators have towards their PokÃ©mon lends itself to making strong bonds with their partners. And this willingness on the part of their PokÃ©mon to do their best can make all the difference.<br>
''Coordinators'' are rare in settings without PokÃ©mon Contests, but thatâ€™s not to say they cannot be used there. Coordinators can represent trainers who train their PokÃ©mon with poise and polish, and value cohesion and dependency over risky maneuvers.<br>

* ''Coordinator''
** [Class]
** Prerequisites: Grace; Charm 3, Command 3, Guile 3, Intimidate 3, or Intuition 3
** At-Will â€“ Free Action
** Effect: Your PokÃ©mon may reroll a single Appeal Roll or Damage Roll. This Ability may be used only once per Contest, and once per PokÃ©mon per Scene.

* ''Decisive Director''
** [Orders]
** Prerequisites: Coordinator
** At-Will â€“ Standard Action
** Target: A PokÃ©mon
** Effect: Add or subtract X from the targetâ€™s Initiative until the end of your next turn. X is equal to your Charm Rank doubled.

* ''Adaptable Performance''
** Prerequisites: Coordinator
** Scene â€“ Free Action
** Trigger: Your PokÃ©monâ€™s Turn to use a Move in a Contest
** Effect: Choose two of your PokÃ©monâ€™s Moves. Your PokÃ©mon may perform your Contest Move as if had the Contest Typing of one of your chosen Moves, and had the effects of the other. You may not use either move on the next round of the contest. This effect may be used once per Contest.

* ''Flexible Preparations''
** Prerequisites: Adaptable Performance; Charm 4, Command 4, Guile 4, Intimidate 4, or Intuition 4
** Daily â€“ Extended Action
** Target: A PokÃ©mon that has Contest Stats from Poffins
** Effect: The target may reallocate up to 2d6 of Poffin-Derived Contest Stats from one Contest Stat to another. This effect lasts until the end of the day.

* ''Innovation''
** Prerequisites: Adaptable Performance
** Daily â€“ Extended Action
** Target: A PokÃ©mon with at least 1 Tutor Point.
** Effect: The target loses 1 Tutor Point, and then learns a Move created with Innovation. See the next section for details on creating Moves for this Feature. A PokÃ©mon may only have one Move created by Innovation at a time.

* ''Nuanced Performance''
** Prerequisites: Coordinator; Charm 5, Command 5, Guile 5, Intimidate 5, or Intuition 5
** 1 AP â€“ Free Action
** Trigger: Your PokÃ©mon miss all targets with a Move
** Effect: That Moveâ€™s Frequency is not expended. This does not work with Moves that may fail to activate, such as moves with the Execute keyword.

* ''Reliable Performance''
** Prerequisites: Nuanced Performance; Charm 6, Command 6, Guile 6, Intimidate 6, or Intuition 6
** 2 AP â€“ Free Action
** Trigger: Your PokÃ©mon makes an Appeal Roll, Accuracy Check, or Skill Check
** Effect: For appeal rolls, instead of making the Appeal Roll, you gain 1 Appeal Point for each Dice you would have rolled. For Accuracy Checks, act as if you had rolled a 10. For Skill Checks, multiply 3.5 by your PokÃ©monâ€™s Skill Rank, and use the resulting number as the result of your roll, rounded down. For all rolls, add or subtract any modifiers as normal.

! Innovation Moves
* The Coordinatorâ€™s â€œInnovationâ€ Feature lets the Coordinator create new Moves for their PokÃ©mon. These Moves can serve to fill voids in Move Lists for both Battles and Contests and provide utility.
* To create a Move, first choose a Contest Type. This affects the Moveâ€™s effects and of course its role in Contests.
* Next choose a Contest Effect. Look at the [[Contest Effects|Contest Effects]] section for the full list. Pick one. Thatâ€™s right, any of them. This determines what the Move does during a Contest, of course.
* Third, choose one of the four templates below. This determines the Moveâ€™s effects in Battle. These are modified by the Contest Type of the Move. Remember, Cool is associated with Attack, Tough with Defense, Beauty with Special Attack, Smart with Special Defense, and Cute with Speed.
* And finally, name your Move! This is the best part!

* ''Template #1''
** Type: Normal
** Frequency: Scene
** AC: None
** Class: Status
** Range: Self
** Effect: The user generates 3 Contest Boons. These may be used as a Swift Action on their turn to gain one of the effects below, based on this Moveâ€™s Contest Type.
*** Beauty: Use when declaring an attack (before Accuracy Roll) to gain a +3 bonus to Effect Range for that attack.
*** Cool: Use when declaring an attack (before Accuracy Roll) to gain a +3 bonus to Critical Hit Range for that attack.
*** Cute: Use during your turn to gain +3 Evasion for one full round.
*** Smart: Use when declaring an attack (before Accuracy Roll) to gain a +3 bonus to Accuracy for that attack.
*** Tough: Use at the start of a turn to avoid all loss of Hit Points from Status Afflictions, Weather, and Recoil for that turn.

* ''Template #2''
** Type: Normal
** Frequency: Scene x2
** AC: None
** Class: Status
** Range: 6, 1 Target
** Effect: The target has the Stat associated with this Moveâ€™s Contest Type lowered by -2 Combat Stages. This Move cannot miss.

* ''Template #3''
** Type: Varies
** Frequency: EOT
** AC: Varies
** Class: Varies
** Range: Varies, Spirit Surge
** Effect: Make a Struggle Attack, increasing the damage roll by +5. Follow all other normal rules for making Struggle attacks, including any modifications from capabilities, features, or special effects. On 18+, the userâ€™s Stat associated with the Contest Type of this Move is raised by +1 Combat Stage. This Moveâ€™s Effect Range is extended by +1 for every two Contest Dice the user has that matches this Moveâ€™s Contest Type.

* ''Template #4''
** Type: Normal
** Frequency: Scene
** AC: None
** Class: Status
** Range: Burst 2
** Effect: All allies in the Burst besides the user gain +1 Combat Stage in the Stat associated with the Contest Type of this Move.






* All Decimals Round Down 3.99 still equals 3
* Percents Add, Not Multiply eg, 20% + 30% = 50%







! Damage Calculation

# Find the attack's ''damage base''
# If the attack has ''STAB'', increase the damage base by +2
# ''Roll the dice'' corresponding to the damage base (chart below)
# If the attack was ''critical'', double the damage roll
# Add the attacker's ''attack'' or ''special attack''
# Subtract the defender's ''defense'' or ''special defense''
#* [[Type Match-up Chart|Type Effectiveness Chart]]
# If the attack was ''effective'' multiply the damage dealt by...
#* 1x Effective = 1.5x Damage
#* 2x Effective = 2x Damage
#* 3x Effective = 3x Damage
# if the attack was ''resisted'' multiply the damage dealt by...
#* 1x Resisted = 0.5x Damage (1/2)
#* 2x Resisted = 0.25x Damage (1/4)
#* 3x Resisted = 0.125x Damage (1/8)
# Apply the final damage to the target's HP.
# If the attack's damage was at least 50% of the target's max HP, add one ''injury''
# Add one ''injury'' if the target falls below 50% of their max HP, or for each multiple of 50% beyond that. If the target healed and is hit again to below 50%, they still gain a new injury.

! Damage Base
<table>
<tr><td>Damage<br>Base</td> <td>Min/''Avg''/Max</td> <td>Damage<br>Roll</td>
<td></td><td>Damage<br>Base</td> <td>Min/''Avg''/Max</td> <td>Damage<br>Roll</td></tr>
<tr><td>''1''</td><td>2 / ''5'' / 7</td><td>1d6+1</td>
<td></td><td>''15''</td><td>24 / ''45'' / 60</td><td>4d10+20</td></tr>
<tr><td>''2''</td><td>4 / ''7'' / 9</td><td>1d6+3</td>
<td></td><td>''16''</td><td>25 / ''50'' / 70</td><td>5d10+20</td></tr>
<tr><td>''3''</td><td>6 / ''9'' / 11</td><td>1d6+5</td>
<td></td><td>''17''</td><td>30 / ''60'' / 85</td><td>5d12+25</td></tr>
<tr><td>''4''</td><td>7 / ''11'' / 14</td><td>1d8+6</td>
<td></td><td>''18''</td><td>31 / ''65'' / 97</td><td>6d12+25</td></tr>
<tr><td>''5''</td><td>9 / ''13'' / 16</td><td>1d8+8</td>
<td></td><td>''19''</td><td>36 / ''70'' / 102</td><td>6d12+30</td></tr>
<tr><td>''6''</td><td>10 / ''15'' / 20</td><td>2d6+8</td>
<td></td><td>''20''</td><td>41 / ''75'' / 107</td><td>6d12+35</td></tr>
<tr><td>''7''</td><td>12 / ''17'' / 22</td><td>2d6+10</td>
<td></td><td>''21''</td><td>46 / ''80'' / 112</td><td>6d12+40</td></tr>
<tr><td>''8''</td><td>12 / ''19'' / 26</td><td>2d8+10</td>
<td></td><td>''22''</td><td>51 / ''85'' / 117</td><td>6d12+45</td></tr>
<tr><td>''9''</td><td>12 / ''21'' / 30</td><td>2d10+10</td>
<td></td><td>''23''</td><td>56 / ''90'' / 122</td><td>6d12+50</td></tr>
<tr><td>''10''</td><td>13 / ''24'' / 34</td><td>3d8+10</td>
<td></td><td>''24''</td><td>61 / ''95'' / 127</td><td>6d12+55</td></tr>
<tr><td>''11''</td><td>13 / ''27'' / 40</td><td>3d10+10</td>
<td></td><td>''25''</td><td>66 / ''100'' / 132</td><td>6d12+60</td></tr>
<tr><td>''12''</td><td>13 / ''30'' / 46</td><td>3d12+10</td>
<td></td><td>''26''</td><td>72 / ''110'' / 149</td><td>7d12+65</td></tr>
<tr><td>''13''</td><td>14 / ''35'' / 50</td><td>4d10+10</td>
<td></td><td>''27''</td><td>78 / ''120'' / 166</td><td>8d12+70</td></tr>
<tr><td>''14''</td><td>19 / ''40'' / 55</td><td>4d10+15</td>
<td></td><td>''28''</td><td>88 / ''130'' / 176</td><td>8d12+80</td></tr>
</table>






''Dances'' have been important parts of celebrations and rituals since the birth of civilization. Whether used for simple entertainment or for significant religious ceremonies and practices, dance has been passed down through the ages just like music, storytelling, and other artistic traditions. No one can say exactly when dance became an integral part of human culture, but itâ€™s clear from observing PokÃ©mon such as Spinda and Maractus that it has been an important part of life for many living things since before the time of man.
''A Dancer'' has learned to apply the art of dance to life as a PokÃ©mon Trainer in a variety of ways, ranging from teaching their PokÃ©mon elegance and tempo to augment their fighting capabilities to applying the acrobatic maneuvers of dance to their own battle techniques. This makes the Dancer a flexible Class that can appeal to many different Trainers. Martial Artists may use the Class to supplement their offensive Moves while Ace Trainers and other more passive Classes may use Dancer Features to play a more active support role in battles.

* ''Dancer''
** [Class] [+Speed]
** Prerequisites: Acrobatics 3; Athletics 3 or Charm 3
** Effect: Choose Spinning Dance or Own Tempo. You gain the chosen Ability.

* ''Mechanic â€“ Dance Moves:''
** Dance Moves you create with the Dance Form Feature look like the Move below. First, name the Dance Move whatever you like. Secondly, choose two Combat Stage gains for the effect. This may either be +2 Combat Stages to a single Stat, like Swords Dance, or +1 Combat Stage to two different Stats, like Dragon Dance. Once chosen, this cannot be changed. Dragon Dance, Quiver Dance, and Swords Dance count as Dance Moves for the purposes of Dancer Features as well. A Dance Moveâ€™s Contest Type must be chosen from a Contest Type associated with a Stat that the Dance Move affects. Cool is associated with Attack, Tough is associated with Defense, Beauty is associated with Special Attack, Smart is associated with Special Defense, and Cute is associated with Speed.

*** Name
*** Type: Normal
*** Frequency: EOT
*** AC: None
*** Class: Status
*** Range: Self
*** Effect:
*** Contest Type:
***Contest Effect: Get Ready!

* ''Dance Form''
** [+Speed]
** Prerequisites: Dancer
** Effect: Create and learn two Dance Moves, plus one more for each other Dancer Feature you have. Whenever you gain another Dancer Feature, create and learn another Dance Move.

* ''Beguiling Dance''
** [+Speed]
** Prerequisites: Dance Form
** Effect: When creating Dance Moves, you can choose to create a Dance Move that has Range: 4, 1 Target, AC 3, and lowers a Combat Stat (chosen at creation) by -2 Combat Stages. This Move is otherwise the same as other Dance Moves you could create except that Dance Moves created with this template have the Contest Effect Excitement instead of Get Ready!.

* ''Dance Practice''
** [+Speed]
** Prerequisites: Dancer
** At-Will â€“ Extended Action
** Target: Your PokÃ©mon with at least 2 Tutor Points
** Effect: The target loses 2 Tutor Points and gains your choice of Spinning Dance or Own Tempo. Dance Practice may target a PokÃ©mon only once.

* ''Choreographer''
** [+Speed]
** Prerequisites: Dance Form; Acrobatics 4, Athletics 4, or Charm 4
** At-Will â€“ Extended Action
** Target: Your PokÃ©mon with at least 2 Tutor Points
** Effect: The target loses 2 Tutor Point and learns a Dance Move created by yourself. Choreographer may target a PokÃ©mon multiple times.

* ''Power Pirouette''
** [+Speed]
** Prerequisites: Dance Form; Acrobatics 5, Athletics 5, or Charm 5
** Scene x2 â€“ Swift Action
** Trigger: You perform a Dance Move
** Effect: Choose one effect:
*** All adjacent targets are Confused.
*** You gain +1 Combat Stage to a Stat of your choice not raised by the triggering Move.
*** Destroy all Hazards within 5 meters, and remove Leech Seed, Trapped, and Stuck from yourself.

* ''Passing Waltz''
** [+Speed]
** Prerequisites: Dance Practice; Acrobatics 6, Athletics 6, or Charm 6
** 1 AP â€“ Free Action
** Trigger: You or one of your PokÃ©mon with Own Tempo or Spinning Dance uses a Dance Move
** Effect: Choose an ally within 3 meters of the triggering target. That ally gains Combat Stages from the triggering Move instead of the user.












''Druids'' are trainers in-tune with that which grows in the earth. Some may herald themselves as protectors of nature, others as mere observers. Yet others still might only be interested in the power that the untamed wilderness can offer them. But all have the same in common - they are one with the forest, and will use the myriad abilities of nature to turn their enemies into mulch. If you anger one, youâ€™d best make like a treeâ€¦ and leave.<br>

* ''Druid''
** [Class] [Special]
** Prerequisites: Elemental Connection (Grass), Novice Survival, Novice General Education
** Effect: Your powers begin to take after either Flowers, Fungi, or Trees. Depending on your oath, you gain an Ability and Stat Tags. Whenever you gain a Druid Feature, you gain the same Stat Tags.
*** Flower Oath - Aroma Veil - [+Special Attack]
*** Fungal Oath - Effect Spore - [+Special Defense]
*** Wood Oath - Life Force - [+Attack]

* ''Green Path''
** Prerequisites: Druid
** Effect: You gain the Naturewalk (Grassland) and Naturewalk (Forest) capabilities, and you are immune to Moves with the Powder keyword.

* ''Overgrowth''
** Prerequisites: Natureâ€™s Embrace Rank 3
** 2 AP â€“ Swift Action
** Trigger: You hit with a Druid Move
** Effect: One target of the triggering Move is afflicted with Overgrowth. As long as the target is afflicted, they are one step less Resistant to Grass-Type attacks, to a maximum of neutral damage, and they cannot recover Hit Points or gain Temporary Hit Points. Whenever they would do so, you gain those Hit Points or Temporary Hit Points instead. Overgrowth is removed when the target Takes a Breather or is hit by a damaging Fire, Ice, Poison, Flying, or Bug-Type attack. Overgrowth may only affect a target once per Scene.

* ''Druid's Call''
** Prerequisites: Green Path
** Scene x2 â€“ Standard Action
** Effect: 6 small saplings, flowery bushes, or mushroom patches (depending on your oath) suddenly grow within 6 meters of you, occupying 1 square each. This vegetation lasts until the end of the encounter, and acts as rough terrain that blocks line of sight for PokÃ©mon and Trainers without the Naturewalk (Forest) Capability. Whenever you use a Move learned through Nature's Embrace, you may have it originate from these Plants as if they were the user. This Feature must be used on soil, or terrain under which soil is hidden by only a few inches (such as most sidewalks, parking lots, gravel or woodchip lots, etc.)

* ''Nature's Embrace''
** [Ranked 3]
** Rank 1 Prerequisites: Druid
** Rank 2 Prerequisites: Survival 4 or General Education 4
** Rank 3 Prerequisites: Survival 5 or General Education 5
** Effect: You learn 2 Moves chosen from the list below, marked with the Rank of this Feature you are gaining or lower.
** <table>
<tr><th>Rank 1 Moves</th><th>Rank 2 Moves</th><th>Rank 3 Moves</th></tr>
<tr><td>
<tr><th>Move</th><th>Prerequisites</th></tr>
<tr><td>Cotton Spore</td><td>None</td></tr>
<tr><td>Ingrain</td><td>Tree Oath</td></tr>
<tr><td>Mega Drain</td><td>None</td></tr>
<tr><td>Razor Leaf</td><td>None</td></tr>

</td><td>

<tr><td>Aromatherapy</td><td>Flower Oath</td></tr>
<tr><td>Energy Ball</td><td>None</td></tr>
<tr><td>Giga Drain</td><td>Fungal Oath</td></tr>
<tr><td>Magical Leaf</td><td>None</td></tr>

</td></tr></table>






''Duelists'' mark their foes and then let their PokÃ©mon tear them apart with ruthless efficiency. Even in the midst of a crowded battlefield, they are able to pinpoint priority targets and ensure their PokÃ©mon have the focus to take them down without distraction. Unlike Jugglers, who prefer to rotate through their entire roster of PokÃ©mon quickly in a battle, Duelists battle with one PokÃ©mon at a time, building up momentum and pushing their advantage further and further.<br>
''Trainers with'' primarily passive PokÃ©mon support options can take advantage of Duelistâ€™s unique and powerful Orders, filling their Standard Actions. This makes Duelist a good counterpart to Classes such as Ace Trainer and Stat Ace.<br>

* ''Duelist''
** [Class]
** Prerequisites: Focused Training, Focus 3
** At-Will â€“ Swift Action
** Target: A PokÃ©mon or Trainer
** Effect: The Foe becomes Tagged; or if the foe is already Tagged, the foe loses the Tag. Only one foe can be Tagged this way at a time. If a new Foe is Tagged, all other Tags are lost.
** Your PokÃ©mon under the effects of Focused Training gain half their Momentum (rounded up) as a Bonus to Accuracy and Evasion against Tagged Foes, but as long as a Foe is Tagged, they do not benefit from Focused Trainingâ€™s Accuracy Bonus against other foes.
** ''Mechanic â€“ Momentum:''
*** Your PokÃ©mon begins each Scene with 0 Momentum.
*** At the end of each Combat round, your PokÃ©mon gains +1 Momentum.
*** Whenever your PokÃ©mon hits a Tagged foe, they gain +1 Momentum.
*** Your PokÃ©mon has a maximum of 6 Momentum. So use a d6 to track it.
*** All Momentum is lost when your PokÃ©mon Faints, your PokÃ©mon is recalled, or combat ends.

* ''Expend Momentum''
** [Orders]
** Prerequisites: Duelist
** At-Will â€“ Standard Action
** Target: Your PokÃ©mon under the effects of Focused Training
** Effect: Apply one of the following effects on the target by spending that much Momentum.
*** Spend 1 Momentum: Your PokÃ©mon regains use of a EOT Frequency Move.
*** Spend 2 Momentum: Your PokÃ©mon automatically rolls an 11 on one d20 Roll of your choice on their next turn.
*** Spend 3 Momentum: Your PokÃ©mon regains a use of Scene Frequency Move. May be chosen only once per Scene per PokÃ©mon.

* ''Effective Methods''
** Prerequisites: Duelist
** At-Will â€“ Extended Action
** Target: Your PokÃ©mon with at least 2 Tutor Points remaining
** Effect: Your PokÃ©mon loses 2 Tutor Points and gains your choice of the Exploit or Tolerance Ability. You may only target a PokÃ©mon once with Effective Methods.

* ''Directed Focus''
** Prerequisites: Effective Methods
** Effect: Whenever your PokÃ©mon with the Exploit or Tolerance Ability are targeted by an [Order], deal Super-Effective Damage, or take Super-Effective Damage, they gain +1 Momentum after all effects of the Move or Order are resolved.

* ''Type Methodology''
** Prerequisites: Effective Methods,  Focus 4
** Scene x2 â€“ Free Action
** Trigger: See Effect
** Effect: Effects depend on whether your PokÃ©mon has the Tolerance or Exploit ability.
*** Whenever your PokÃ©mon with Tolerance takes Super-Effective damage from a Tagged foe, your PokÃ©mon may lose 2 Momentum to Resist that attack one step.
*** Whenever your PokÃ©mon with Exploit deals Resisted damage to a Tagged foe, your PokÃ©mon may lose 2 Momentum to increase the effectiveness of the attack one step.

* ''Duelistâ€™s Manual''
** [Orders]
** Prerequisites: Expend Momentum, Effective Methods, Focus 5
** 2 AP â€“ Standard Action
** Target: Your PokÃ©mon under the effects of Focused Training
** Effect: Apply one of the following effects. To choose an effect, your PokÃ©mon must have a certain amount of Momentum. (Duelistâ€™s Manual does not spend Momentum).
*** 1 Momentum: Your PokÃ©mon doubles their bonuses from Tolerance or Exploit until the end of their next turn and may change their Tolerance Ability into Exploit, or vice versa, until the end of their next turn.
*** 2 Momentum: Your PokÃ©monâ€™s next Pass, Cone, Close Blast, or Burst attack becomes a single target Melee attack, or their next Line or Ranged Blast attack becomes a single target Ranged attack. If this attack hits, the target becomes Vulnerable for one full round and has their Initiative set to 0 until the end of their next turn.
*** 3 Momentum: Your PokÃ©mon may act while ignoring the Confused, Rage, Infatuation, and Suppressed Volatile Status on their next turn as long as they attempt to attack a Tagged foe. May only be used once per Scene per PokÃ©mon.

* ''Seize The Moment''
** Prerequisites: Duelist, Master Focus
** Scene x2 â€“ Free Action
** Trigger: Your PokÃ©mon would gain Momentum while already at 6 Momentum
** Effect: Your PokÃ©mon loses 6 Momentum, and then gains +1 Momentum. Your PokÃ©mon may immediately make an attack as an Interrupt, but this attack must target only a Tagged Foe. If the attack misses, it still deals damage as if it had the Smite keyword. If the attack hits, itâ€™s automatically a Critical Hit. If it would have already been a Critical Hit, your PokÃ©mon gains Hit Points equal to half of its maximum Hit Points. May be used only once per Scene per PokÃ©mon .






''The earth'' is the very foundation that the worldâ€™s life lives on. Little by little, it moves, unceasingly changing itself bit by bit. Continents drift. Volcanoes rise. The earth quakes, shakes and cracks open. Those with the steady, unyielding nature of the land are Earth Shakers. As unflinching as the ground itself, these souls control the very substance on which they - and their enemies - stand. Whether the earth parts, the sand streams, or balance is lost, these patient trainers will overcome any odds to ensure they and their allies are the only ones left standing on solid ground.<br>

* ''Earth Shaker''
** [Class] [+Defense]
** Prerequisites: Elemental Connection (Ground), Novice Intuition, Novice Focus
** Effect: Pick two of Bulldoze, Mud Shot, or Sand-Attack. You learn the chosen Moves.

* ''Earthen Bond''
** [+Defense]
** Prerequisites: Earth Shaker
** Effect: You gain the Tremorsense Capability, and you gain Naturewalk for Cave, Mountain and Desert.

* ''Earth Motherâ€™s Blessing''
** [Ranked 2] [+Defense]
** Rank 1 Prerequisites: Adept Focus or Intuition
** Rank 2 Prerequisites: Ground Out, Focus 6 or Intuition 6
** Effect: Each Rank, choose Arena Trap or Lightning Rod. You gain the chosen Ability.

* ''Earthshifter''
** [+Defense]
** Prerequisites: Ground Out
** 2 AP â€“ Swift Action
** Trigger: You hit with a damaging Ground Type Move
** Effect: You initiate a Trip Maneuver against 1 target of the Move. The Maneuver automatically hits, and you may use your Focus or Intuition for the opposed check.

* ''Ground Out''
** [+Defense]
** Prerequisites: Earth Shaker, Focus 5 or Intuition 5
** Effect: Pick two of Drill Run, Magnitude, or Mud Bomb. You learn the chosen Moves.

* ''Tectonic Shift''
** [+Defense]
** Prerequisites: Ground Out, Focus 6 or Intuition 6
** Effect: Pick two of Earthquake, Earth Power, or Sand Tomb. You learn the chosen Moves.

** Size: Small
** Weight Class: 1
